title: CTRL0000929718 - Transcribed Interview of Dustin Thompson, (Nov. 16, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 9:04 a.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is a transcribed interview of Mr. Dustin
Thompson, conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th
Attack on the United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'll ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
Again, this will be a staff-led interview, although members may of course choose
to come in and ask questions.
with us, but we'll announce them if any of them do arrive.
investigative counsel for the select committee.
, investigative c o u n s e l ; _ ,
At this time, there are no members who are in the room
At this time, could counsel for the witness please state their name for the record?
My name is Andrew Stewart, S-t-e-w-a-r-t.
There is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
until each question is completed before you begin your response, and we will try to wait
until your response is complete before asking another question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses, like shaking your head or
nodding your head, so it's important that you answer each question with an audible,
We ask you that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection of
If you don't, I may prompt you.
If a question is not clear, please ask us to repeat it.
recognized by the select committee, like the Fifth Amendment right against
You may only refuse to answer a question to preserve a privilege
The first key point that I want to underscore is that this interview is voluntary.
at any time you'd like to stop speaking with us, please say so.
Similarly, if at any point you wish to discuss something with your attorney in
private, please let us know, and we'll take a break so you both can have that
Second, this interview is not under oath.
However, because this is still a formal
select committee investigatory proceeding, you are obligated under Federal law to tell
the truth to Congress, the same as if you were speaking with the FBI or the DOJ.
It is deliberately unlawful to provide -- sorry.
could result in criminal penalties for perjury and/or false statements.
For this interview, providing false information
Third, you are not obligated to keep the fact of this interview and what we discuss
prosecutor or judge on your case, or you can tell no one at all.
You are free to tell whomever you wish that you met with us, including the
However, we will not disclose the contents of what we discuss today until properly
authorized for release by the chair and the rest of the committee.
Fourth, the select committee is separate and independent from the
the DOJ is not a partner with the select committee and its investigation whatsoever.
The select committee also is not a party to your criminal case and is not agreeing
We have no involvement with their ongoing prosecutions, and
to submit anything on your behalf to your judge.
So, to recap logistics, please let us know if you need any breaks or
would like to discuss anything with your attorney.
hour mark, just to make sure we all have enough stamina to get through the entire
We'll try to take a break at about the
And, as I mentioned earlier, there may be several people asking questions.
- a n d - w i l l chime in, and I'll be pausing at certain points to see if they
please simply ask us to repeat it or rephrase it.
And, as with me, if they ask a question you don't understand,
So we'll start with a few background questions just to begin.
How long have you lived there?
And what is your educational background?
I graduated from the Ohio State University 2008 or '09.
And what do you do for a living?
Previously, I was doing furniture repair.
I've kind of bounced around; I've
But that was my last one I was doing up until trial.
And throughout the time in question -- we're talking about 2020 into
2021 -- what were you doing for your career?
I was doing pest control up until March of 2020, and then I was laid off on
Then I was unemployed until January 9th of '22.
Was that related to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic?
So, going back to that general timeframe, early to mid-2020, how closely would
So you say you were laid off in March 2020; is that correct?
you say you were following political events throughout former President Trump's term in
I would say, like, pretty, like -- I don't know -- like, pretty close, I
guess, following stuff, like, daily news and stuff, listening to talk radio when I was
So you say you listened to talk radio.
Were there other sources of information
like cable TV or certain websites that you used to gather information?
For websites, I mean, like, it was Drudge Report and Zero Hedge
were two I went to kind of daily.
I'm gonna run through a couple of social media applications and just ask if you
used any of them to browse for news.
Any particular subreddits, or is that -- r/TheDonald?
Like, it'd be, like, the front page or something.
I would never -- I didn't really understand how to use it.
I've been on it, but for wasting time.
Yeah, I would be on Twitter.
followed Trump, I guess, but, like, outside that, nothing really, normally, political.
There was, like, Qmap.pub was, like, a QAnon website that I'd have, like, posts
about QAnon drops, they were called, like -- and I would check those out.
Could you say the name of that website again?
So would you say you subscribed to QAnon beliefs throughout 2020?
I mean, I found it interesting.
I don't really see, like, an exact belief system.
I feel like it was more asking questions and, you know, letting people come to their own
But, yeah, I guess, you could say I read them and tried to make sense of it.
When would you say you started engaging with QAnon theories?
Do you remember what motivated you to first start engaging with those
Actually, I think I heard a bit about it on YouTube.
I think it was a guy called Plane Medic (ph).
I would say, like, 2019 late, 2020, something like that.
Do you remember what channel or whose YouTube?
And was there any particular issue that attracted you to that corner
It just seemed just inquisitive, you know, really, just to see what it was
And for those of us who aren't as familiar, could you kind of walk
us through in a capsule form what you believed those questions to be going after and
kind of a summation of your engagement with QAnon or what you understood it to be?
I mean, it was about the deep state and people that are controlling
the government for evil instead of good.
I mean, I thought he had involvement in it.
Like -- or, I mean, like, that he -- if he wasn't necessarily contributing to it, he
And how did you view President Trump's relationship to those worries,
was aware of it as well.
And what about his role in this sort of dynamic you described as the deep state
As the head of the government, where does he fit in?
Like, I thought he was, you know, trying to do good, you know.
And you mentioned that you followed the former President on social media, on
Were there any other accounts of his that you followed?
And of the sources of information we just ran through, were there ones that
you relied on more than others, if you had to pick one or two that were most important
I mean, yeah, like, I would kind of just look into each one, like, daily for a few
minutes, you know, to see what was -- what was new.
So, more broadly speaking, did you consider yourself to be a supporter of
And why did you consider yourself to be a supporter?
To be on the side of good.
Could you walk us through that a little bit more?
I mean, it just seemed like he was getting attacked for things unfairly, and I
wanted to -- you know, it felt like he was the underdog.
I kind of wanted to support the
Were there particular issues where you thought he was the underdog or
being attacked that really motivated you to support him?
I wanted to move on, kind of going back to a timeline of 2020, but before I did, I
So I wanted to move back to March 2020.
believe you lost your job due to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic.
you could talk a little bit more about how that impacted your life.
Like, you know, trying to find a new job was really hard during the time.
wanted to be a good husband and, you know, contributing member to the family and
I mean, it was definitely negative.
It was March 17th, the day before my
And just, you know, not having -- like, my routine was all messed up.
And, like, I had just gotten married 3 months prior in January, and I
So did you ever become involved in demonstrations against COVID-19
restrictions that popped up in the spring and the summer?
There was obviously a lot of conversation about
restrictions being put in place, and President Trump was very prominently rallying against
Did you engage in those conversations online?
I just remember, like, the 2 weeks to flatten the curve, you know, and I
thought that was, like, a good idea at the time, but -- no.
And as President Trump continued to sort of speak about these restrictions,
criticize these restrictions, moving into the spring and the summer, do you remember
that being an important element of your support for the former President?
I mean, at the time, like, no.
I didn't really pay much attention -- I feel like
no one knew exactly the best situation, and, you know, people were just trying different
things and, you know, just trying whatever they could, really.
And you talked about checking some news sources daily, going onto some
Would you say that that increased, sort of, after the pandemic
Yeah, because I had more free time.
And were there any ways in which you felt your perception started to
change because you had more time to look at these forums?
So, a couple months after the pandemic began, obviously there were a lot of
activities, protests over the summer, June and July, related to the police killings of George
Were you involved in any of the protests surrounding those events?
do some hiking, and ended up getting a trespassing charge from a park ranger.
yeah, no, I was just trying to get away from that kind of stuff.
Actually, on -- it was Father's Day in July, there was a big protest in my
And I went with a friend to Hocking Hills to just get away from it, try and
You were never involved in any organized counter-protests, anything like
Why did you want to get away from it?
Like, it just -- it almost seemed like -- like a scary event.
people were riding on, like, the hood of trucks and they were, like, taking over the gas
And I was just -- you know, just a lot of banging and yelling around the
Like, I just wanted to get away from it.
And, obviously, over the summer, there was a lot of talk about the involvement of
Were you ever concerned about that, for example, when the event was close to
President Trump talked about that quite a lot on Twitter and
It seemed like it was more of a Black Lives Matter event that was near
my house, but I wasn't sure.
Did you understand those groups to be related, Black Lives Matter and
How did you view President Trump's general posture towards those events over
the summer, if you have any thoughts on that at all?
I mean, I guess I would say, like, the summer of 2020, he didn't think that
some of those were necessarily good, from my opinion.
Are there any instances that you remember specifically?
So, towards the middle of the summer, as these protests were really heating
up, there were several groups that became more prominently involved in
possibility of antifa that was mentioned by President Trump quite a bit, but there were
also documented instances of the Proud Boys and the Oath Keepers and other militia
groups like the Three Percenters kind of being in and around these events.
Black Lives Matter, and I mentioned the
Were you aware of those groups being involved in the events, just through the
And what was your opinion of them generally at that time?
I mean, I didn't know, like, really, like, who was who, and I didn't really try
Yeah, I had seen some altercations on VouTube and stuff, clashes, I guess
And were aware of these groups -- Proud Boys, Oath Keepers -- before the
It just seemed like, you know, people with different political beliefs,
Meaning that the Black Lives Matter activists and the Proud Boys, Oath
And that sense of them fighting, the conflict, was that concerning, was that
alarming to you, reading about it from home?
I mean, it's -- it was concerning, I guess.
It is -- like, I was just -- like, I felt
like the division in America was, you know, at, like, a bad place, probably the worst it's
-- that was my takeaway from it, really.
And, at that point, do you remember anything salient from QAnon forums
talking about the protests and the ensuing unrest?
So, moving into the fall of 2020, do you recall the first time you started to
hear concerns about the potential for election fraud?
Yeah, I don't remember exactly, but I remember -- I don't remember exactly
when it was, but I remember hearing things like, "Yeah, if I don't win, there was fraud," or
Did you have a view on -- talking about before the election -- did you have a
view on these claims that the President was making?
I just thought it was kind of talk.
So, by the time election day 2020 came around, did you believe
that that the election was going to be stolen?
Not -- not -- no, not the day of.
So when did you start to believe that the election may have been stolen?
I guess it would've been, like, the next day.
Like, I just remember it was,
like, 3:00 a.m. and they were like, you know, "We're gonna stop counting votes.
And then, like, at 6:00 a.m., I got up and it was like, "Biden won
And I was like, "I thought you were gonna stop counting the votes."
So did you watch President Trump's speech that night, the early morning of
So, generally, you would say that your beliefs started to shift when
you saw the change in ballot totals the morning after?
And then in the days and weeks after, can you walk us through how your
I mean, at the time, there was a lot of theories, you know, being thrown
around, and I was just trying to follow them.
But, at the time, it looked suspicious, I
And were there any theories that were particularly influential in your mind?
I don't -- I think it was Detroit or something where they were, like, putting up
the poster board over the windows to keep people from looking in.
Were there certain parts of the country -- you just mentioned Detroit.
Were there certain parts of the country that you thought the fraud was most prominent?
I was looking over your trial transcript, and a couple of times you mentioned sort
So, Mr. Thompson, thanks again for taking the time.
of believing the outlandish stuff that Trump was saying at the time.
claims about the election lie, and even to the point that you just didn't think President
Biden could've won because Trump said so.
So I was wondering, you know, trying to square what
here, how much of an influence did President Trump have on your beliefs that the
I mean, I'd say quite a bit.
You know, like, he was the one saying it, and
that's where I was getting all my information from, basically, about the election, was
from, you know, Trump and the news, you know.
But, basically, when he said it, I
And I'm hoping you can extrapolate on that a little bit.
Was is something about his personality, his politics, anything like that?
I mean, like, yeah, he was a good speaker and, you know -- but I just believed
I mean, outside of just saying, like, you know, I wanted to.
Were you talking to any friends or family or even, you know, people on line
who might have disagreed with you about the election claims?
I mean, I know I was talking to a buddy that also believed it was stolen and
some other people that said it wasn't, but yeah.
And how did those conversations with people who didn't think the
I mean, like, they just didn't think that he -- that Trump won, and they
And we kind of just agreed to disagree first and --
Did you ever, you know, search on line for evidence to counterbalance your
view of what President Trump was saying?
Did you ever try to check his claims?
Yeah, no, that's something I've realized in hindsight, but no.
just checking stuff that kind of affirmed his story and nothing related to the contrary at
BYKind of building on that point, President Trump was making a lot of claims
about the election being stolen that had differing modes, differing culprits.
question would be to you, who did you think was responsible for the fraud, the stealing of
I would say, like, just the way that the ballots were counted seemed
So just the people who counted the votes.
So did you think there was some kind of organizational effort behind it or
I mean, like, I just -- I mean, I thought, like, there were people -- there were
ballots that were counted that shouldn't have been counted, in places.
And you mentioned earlier both the idea of your personal support of
President Trump being premised on the idea that he was a bit of an underdog and then
also your engagement with that QAnon forum, and you explained that to sort of be an
idea of the deep state controlling the government.
So I'm curious to hear how, if at all, those two ideas factored into your belief that
The QAnon thing doesn't really factor in to me believing the election was
It was more just, like, the stories, like, that Trump was saying, yeah, that made
Did you believe President Trump had been targeted for defeat by
Yeah, I guess you could say that.
What did you think could happen if President Trump and his supporters
refused to say that his defeat was valid?
So, when President Trump was pushing for recounts and stopping the count,
Did you think there was a chance he could stay
I felt like it was already decided and it was gonna happen regardless
you didn't think there was any point to it?
At that point, no, I did think -- yeah, the recounts.
chance at that time that something could be uncovered or discovered that could turn the
election, as far as, like, counting the ballots and stuff was concerned.
So, in the first couple of weeks after the election, you
thought there was a real chance that the result could be overturned.
But then at some point, once those efforts failed, you figured there
But President Trump, obviously, kept that drumbeat of claims going even after the
recounts failed and after those calls to stop the count failed.
his continued claims of fraud at that point?
I mean, like, I thought he believed them.
kind of believe them too, that there was fraud.
But it seemed like it was possible, and I believed that.
And, like, I thought there was -- I
But I don't know exactly where or what.
So, obviously, there was a lot of organizing on the ground surrounding the
And I'm curious if you participated in any activities to protest the
Did you ever travel to D.C. for events in November or December?
Did you make any financial contributions to "stop the steal" efforts?
At this point did you have any affiliation with Proud Boys, the Oath Keepers?
And we've talked a little bit about QAnon.
How would you say your engagement
with QAnon forums changed in the weeks and months after the election?
From what I recall, like, he wasn't really -- it wasn't really saying much about
the election, but, like, I mean, if there was, like, a new post, I would kind of just go to it,
read it, and then kind of see what other people were saying about it.
And did you think that there was any prominent threat posed by antifa in
You didn't think they had anything to do with the theft of the election?
And so at some point you said that you stopped believing that there was
anything that could be done to reverse President Trump's loss.
So you said at some point you thought that it was game over and
that you couldn't overturn President Trump's loss, there was nothing he can do.
Like, I would say it was probably towards the end of December, you know,
I'd say mid-December, end of December is when I first thought it
was over, if not a little sooner.
So that was before you decided to come to D.C. for January 6th?
So can you tell us more about the factors that influenced your decision to
I just remember Trump saying it was gonna be, like, I think it was, a wild
And, like, you know, I felt like I wanted to go because, like, I hadn't gotten out,
hadn't been around people in a while, and, you know, these were gonna be, like,
like-minded people, you know, kind of, like, my people that I agree with.
Do you recall when you first decided to travel to Washington?
It was just the day before or 2 days before.
You mentioned that President Trump said it was gonna be a wild time.
There was a tweet on December 19th where President Trump first mentioned January 6th
and said, "Be there, will be wild!"
Do you recall seeing that tweet?
I don't think I saw it at the time.
It was later in the month that I saw it, if
But what do you think President Trump meant by "wild"?
I mean, I thought it was just kind of gonna be like a going-out celebration,
like a retirement party or something, but -- you know, makes sense.
So you didn't think at that point when you were reading about what he was saying
about the event, what others were saying, you didn't think that there was a chance it
would result in him staying in the White House?
Mr. Thompson, you mentioned seeing the tweet later or, you know, you
knew that it would be a wild time.
event was sometimes called "stop the steal" event.
The tweet also talks about the "stop the steal" -- the
Did you really think that it was only going to be sort of a retirement party?
did you expect President Trump to continue to claim the election was stolen?
I figured he would continue to claim it.
I didn't know it was a "stop the
I remember seeing a lot of signs when I got there about that.
of thought it was, like, a forgone conclusion by that point, that there was no stopping it,
And were people who were talking about going to January 6th, or anyone
else on line, were you also seeing other people say they expected January 6th to be this
I mean, I didn't really see anybody saying anything about what they
So, obviously, the event was branded "Save America."
also part of the branding on line for the event.
Did that in any way conflict with your idea that it would be a retirement party?
was nothing really that could be done to stop the steal.
You know, like, I mean, I just thought at that point there
So what websites or social media apps did you review to find more
I believe it was just, like, Twitter, probably, where I got information about
Did you ever join any groups on Facebook or elsewhere about the rally?
I was never on Face book.
I wasn't on any Twitter groups or anything
So, ultimately, what would you say was your goal in traveling to D.C. on
Just to be with like-minded people and, you know, just to have a good time.
Were you concerned about the potential for violence?
And why did you think it was important for you to be there?
Because I felt like it was, like, the last -- like, my only chance to see Trump
and, like -- so, like, the last chance to kind of see him and be around his supporters,
So I wanted to move more into your arrival to D.C. and your preparation to come,
but, before I do, I wanted to see if
Mr. Thompson, so, not to harp on this too much, but in your trial
transcript -- you know, we'll get to the speech as you're listening to it.
the speech, you mentioned you felt that President Trump was talking about democracy
being at risk, the country being destroyed.
Were any of those thoughts in your mind ahead of January 6th?
believe -- like, since you believed the election was stolen, did you hope that this rally
would do something to, you know, prevent the end of American democracy?
Mr. Thompson, when did you actually leave from Columbus to travel to D.C.?
It was the night of the 5th.
Like, I believe it was, like -- it was late, about 6:00 or 7:00 p.m.
So you said you had decided a couple of days beforehand.
Yeah, if not -- I mean, I think, really, kind of decided it the day before, on the
And it was just kind of figuring out -- like, I was gonna go, maybe, with two
people, and then it just ended up being one other person.
And who was that other person?
That drove, was Robert, my co-defendant.
And we left that night of the
And how did you know Mr. Lyon?
We have been friends for a while.
And did Mr. Lyon express similar ideas to you about what January 6th was?
Kind of met through another friend,
He wanted to go kind of because he thought it would be
Whose idea was it to travel to D.C.?
I believe it was my idea to go.
And did you end up staying in D.C. or somewhere else surrounding?
I believe we stayed in Maryland.
And you arrived the night of the 5th.
We got there early morning, like, 1:00 or 2:00 a.m., so we just checked
And do you remember where in Maryland you stayed, the name of the
Did you meet up with anyone when you got there, or you just went right to
No, we just went straight to sleep.
We had tried to find some food and
everywhere was closed, so we just went to bed.
And I know I asked this before, but I wanted to reiterate.
to be any violence the next day?
Did you do anything to prepare yourself for the next day?
I mean, like, besides, you know, packing some drinks and, like, we
brought, like, a Bluetooth speaker kind of stuff, but outside of that, no.
Did you bring any equipment with you?
No vests, helmets, anything of that sort?
Tell him about the vest you found.
I had found a vest at the Eclipse rally and put it on at that time
before walking to the Capitol, but I didn't bring it with me.
We'll get to that in a few.
And just while we're on the night before, did you have any awareness, going into
So this is the bulletproof vest that you were wearing at the Capitol?
So you found that the next day?
the 6th, that the next day was the day that Congress was going to certify President
Yeah, I was aware of that.
Did you have any awareness of the Vice President's role in overseeing
Not until the day of the 6th did I know that he, Mike Pence, played a role in
But when you went to sleep the night of the 5th, you did not believe there was
anything that you or anyone else could do to influence Congress.
Well, we're just about to get to the 6th itself.
but would you want to take a 10-minute break?
We're at about the halfway point.
We could even do, like, a 5-minute break, if you wanted to do that.
So let's say we'll go back on the record at 9:55?
So we can go back on the record at 9:55 a.m.
So, Mr. Thompson, I know you attended the rally on the Ellipse on the 6th.
you just walk us through what happened when you and Mr. Lyon woke up that morning?
And we'll move now to discuss the events of January 6th itself.
Pretty much, we got up and just kind of cleaned up and got out of
the hotel kind of the quickest (ph) way that we could.
And you, at that point, you went towards the Ellipse?
And I didn't know exactly where to go.
just told the Uber driver to take us where the people were, the Washington Monument,
And could you describe the scene when you got there?
He could only get, like, so close, but we could see people walking, and just
kind of got out and followed them.
And how close did you end up getting to the stage?
At some point, we had circled around, and, like, we could see the stage and
saw, like, the security magna-things to go through, but we didn't wanna go through those.
Just seemed like a hassle; there was this huge line.
watched it on the screen and listened to it on the speakers.
So we just kind of stayed out and
So you did not want to go through the magnetometers.
Yeah, there was a line, so it seemed like a hassle, you know, waiting in the
Could you describe the crowd, what the crowd was like outside of the
It was -- people were happy, joyous.
And, at that point, did you hear people talking about the possibility that you
There was a lot of people.
I think people were saying it, but I -- I guess I don't know what they meant by
So, when you kind of got into the crowd on the morning of the 6th before
the President was speaking, you still were under the impression this was a retirement
And that's kind of why I came to it.
was gonna happen, and I just wanted to be there for it.
I didn't know what it was, but I
felt like it was an important -- important day.
Like -- I mean, I felt like I knew something was gonna happen, but I just
That idea that it was an important day, that was what motivated you to
come in the first place to Washington?
Like, yeah, you can say that, yeah.
And you said "something important, you just didn't know what."
expand on that a little bit?
What kind of things did you think could happen?
Like, I really didn't have any idea.
I just felt like -- I just kind of had that
feeling that something was gonna happen, but I didn't know what.
I thought, like, maybe Trump was gonna do something kind of outlandish or
something, but, I mean, I just -- I didn't know what was gonna happen, but I just felt
So you said you thought Mr. Trump might do something outlandish, and
I just didn't know what he was -- I thought maybe that was a possibility
So the mood of the people, you said, was joyous and happy?
Did you see anyone who appeared to be armed?
Anyone in bulletproof vests, helmets, tactical gear?
Not at the -- not at the Ellipse.
Can I just jump in here real quick?
So did you see anyone who was in that gear on your way
to D.C. or on your way to The Mall?
The crowd seemed that way, yes.
Back to the magnetometers, Mr. Thompson, did you see people, like,
discarding backpacks or putting their clothing or anything else outside of the
Did you see a lot of them?
I was seeing these, like, piles of backpacks and flagpoles.
some people were watching that for other people.
all over the place of stuff like that.
And I just -- there were lots of piles
Did anyone talk about why they were, you know, putting their bags off to the
Were they talking about why they weren't allowed to take them in?
Because they weren't allowed to take them in.
there something in the backpack or on the flag that wasn't allowed in?
I didn't hear them talk about that.
And sorry if I missed this, but can you just remind me about what time you were
What time you saw them -- what time did you see people, like, throwing the
An estimate, like, mid-morning, early morning?
Morning, 11:00, maybe a little later, something like that.
So when you saw those piles of equipment outside of the magnetometers,
did that raise any concern in your mind?
Did it ever occur to you that there could be weapons that could not go
through the magnetometers in those bags?
I felt like -- I had never been to anything where the President was at
before, and so I just felt like, you know, it's the President and he was just very cautious
about, you know, not letting anything in.
And you said that you picked up a bulletproof vest at some point in the morning.
Did that occur during this period when you were outside the magnetometers?
